sp.p: Your Worſhip is ſome Cow-Doctor I warrant. And I think you are a couple of dry haſty, narrow-ſpirited Gentlemen, and ſo fare you well—Exit Medler in a pe • t.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p:
Gentlemen, you complain of my Tenants, that they are croſs grain'd; I doubt it's long of the croſs Queſtions
you put to 'em. I pray thee Speed, call in Mr. Slack; it may be he will fit Father Caſy's humor better.
This man rents a good Farm of me, but he has a good Yeomans Eſtate of his own, and, I believe, lives as eaſily and unconcernedly, as any Lord in the Land.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: I beg your Worſhips pardon, that I have been ſo long. But Mr Slack was ſo deeply ingag'd in company that he knew, and Liquor that he lik'd, that I could not eaſily perſwade him to leave 'em.

sp.speaker: Slack.
sp.p: I know your Worſhip has nothing to ſay to me: For I have but one Concern in the whole World, that is, to pay my Rent; and that your Worſhip knows I have. And as for theſe Gentlemen Strangers, I ſuppoſe they have no more to ſay to me, than I have to them; and that's juſt nothing.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: But what, Sir, does nothing ail you in any reſpect?

sp.speaker: Slack.
sp.p: Not now I have paid my Rent Sir.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: And have no Diſtemper upon you at no time?

sp.speaker: Slack.
sp.p: None but what I cure my ſelf. Sometimes I am hungry, ſometimes thirſty, ſometimes ſleepy; but I have a Remedy at hand for all theſe; and ſuch a Remedy too, as is pleaſant to take.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: But what, are you never weary?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: Never, except it be with doing nothing, or with hearing impertinent Talk, or long ſtories of news.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Or a long Sermon

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: You are i'th' right, Landlord, I had forgot that. But yet I go to Church too ſometimes, to take a Nap. I love the Collects too, only there's ſo many of them; and Sermon too, if it be not too loud to waken me, or too long, to keep me from my Dinner.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.p: I doubt you are Atheiſtically given, Mr. Slack.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p:
I know not what you mean by Atheiſtically. I confeſs I am no great admirer of Orators and Obſervators, nor do I love to have my head troubled with Sermons or Gazets. I cannot endure to be concern'd: Let things go which way they will; for they will go which way they will. What if the Earth quake; muſt my Heart needs
ake? what if the Heaven • crack, does it follow, that my Brains muſt crow? What care I, whether the Pope be a Papiſh or a Proteſtant, whether he be a Man or a Woman, whether he be a Woman or a Devil. What is it to me, whether the King of Germany, and the King of Turky fall out or fall in. It does not concern me ſo much, whether the French King gets Flanders or loſes it, as whether my Flanders Mare in the ſtable be with Foal or no? They have made a great deal of ſtir about reducing of Ireland, as they call it; they might e'en have let it ha' gone for me: If it were all of a Bog, it would not trouble me; I have never a foot of Land there.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.p: But what, have you no mind to know how things go abroad?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: To know Sir? Why I'll tell you, I think it is the wiſeſt way to know nothing: for the more one knows, the more he's vext: It is an eaſier and ſweeter life to be ignorant, than to be a knowing Man.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.p: But if he knows nothing, he's not a Man, he's a Beaſt.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p:
Beaſt, Sir? The life of a Beaſt is not ſo contemptible as you make fair of. I believe there's never a Beaſt I have, would change lives with you. The life of a Beaſt? what life can be eaſier ſweeter, freer? He leads the life of knowing nothing, of caring for nothing: he eats, and drinks, and ſleeps, and deſires nothing, wants nothing, fears nothing. Oh Sir, if men were but as free from Paſſions, and Apprehenſions as the Beaſts are, how happily might they live? We forſooth, fret at what we have, and vex for want of what we have not. We cannot enjoy our ſelves, becauſe any body elſe enjoys any thing as good, or better. We cannot digeſt • n Injury, till we have requited it; nor be reconciled then neither. There is worſe found in the Nature of Men, than in the nature of Beaſts; and all becauſe men can think, and know, and argue, and have the ill luck to be concern'd; which theſe ſilly Beaſts are free from. If you did but know Sir, how ſweet and pleaſant it is to approach as near as may be to the life of a Beaſt, and yet not to be one, you would almoſt be tempted to doff your Periwig and
Coloſhes, and put on Horns and Hooves.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.p: But what, would you die like a Beaſt too.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: Their way of dying? • s all one with yours; they leave breathing, and ſo do you. And their way of burying, much nobler than yours: They are buried in you, whereas you are buried in the Bowels of Fiſhes, of Crows, or at beſt of Worms. My Ox, or my Hog, when he's dead and eaten, comes to be a part of my ſelf; you being dead, turn to Duſt and Eilthineſs. And if you enquire any further, for the Credit of the Beaſt be it ſpoken, he has nothing to anſwer for; which you Divines and Doctors have.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.p: I think, Sr. Francis, you would do well, to make this man your chief Herds-man.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: Content Sir, if you will be Chaplain to the Herd.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Nay rather, Sir Francis, be at ſome Charges with him, to lengthen his Ears, and ſo he will be one ſort of Beaſt preſently.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p:
Gentlemen, I wiſh you no worſe, than that you may always be kept in
your Senſes; and then I'm ſure you will never want ſomething to vex you.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Gentlemen, you do ſo diſturb my Neighbours, that they know not what they ſay. They are a • ittle ſhatter'd, and you make 'em ſ • ark mad. It is to be hoped, if I call in a pair of men that are mad already, you will make 'em ſober. I pray thee, Speed, go and call in hither Mr. Grindon and Frank Fawns. I believe we ſhall have no great trouble with them, except it be to reconcile 'em: and that I hope Father you may do.

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.p: Alas, Sir Francis, your people do not underſtand my Divinity-trade; but I will do what I can for 'em. My work lies in Caſes of Conſcience, and I perceive your people have no Conſcience, that a man can come at.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Oh, it lies deep, Father; but by the Lancet of Inquiſition, or the Horſe-leech of thorough Examination, you may poſſibly come to it and let out ſome bad Blood.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p:
You're welcome, Mr. Grindon, I have invited you in, to know whether
here be any thing, wherein theſe Learned Gentlemen can pleaſure you.

sp.speaker: Grin.
sp.p: Sir, you think ſure, I am a man much given to Pleaſure. If you Knights and Gentlemen lov'd your Pleaſure no more than I do, there would not be ſo much Hunting and Hawking, and breaking of mens Hedges, as there is.

sp.speaker: Faw.
sp.p: I believe, Mr. Grindon, his Worſhip did not mean as you interpret him.

sp.speaker: Grind.
sp.p: Interpret him? I wonder how I came to be an Interpreter, I think all the World has a mind to abuſe me. I can ſcarce read the Text, and yet I muſt be an Interpreter forſooth.

sp.speaker: Faw.
sp.p: I mean Sir, (I pray pardon me) as you underſtand him.

sp.speaker: Grin.
sp.p: What, I am become an underſtanding Man; that to my own Knowledge, was but a Fool when I came in. Ay, and the moſt underſtanding of men too, a •• Pope forſooth, that can pardon. I warrant I am infallible too, am I not?

sp.speaker: Faw.
sp.p: Sir, if I be not deceiv'd, you are infallible, you are a Pope.

sp.speaker: Grin.
sp.p: I a Pope, you Dotterel? how can I be a Pope?

sp.speaker: Faw.
sp.p: You carry a Pope in your Belly, and that's all one.

sp.speaker: Grin.
sp.p: I pray thee Fawns, explain thy ſelf.

sp.speaker: Faw.
sp.p: I am plain enough Mr. Grindon, I need no great Explanation. But my meaning is this: The conceit that you have of your own Underſtanding, is apt to make you ſnarl at the different Sentiments of all other men. Now whoever, (being himſelf ſatisfied in a thing) does thereupon declare, that he will never alter his Opinion, or the Conduct of his Affairs, muſt needs be infallible; at leaſt, he does aſſume an Infallibility to himſelf, as well as the Pope. The Pope ſays, I cannot err; you ſay you will never alter, and I pray then, which is the more infallible?

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.p: I pray, Sir Francis, rebuke this man, he nibbles at the Church.

sp.speaker: Grin.
sp.p:
It's well Sir, he does but nibble at you; he bites me. He ſays I am a Pope, I would he could make his words good. He ſays I ſnarl, as if I were a Dog: but if he could make me a Pope,
I would make Bulls▪ that ſhould puſh this Dog out of the Church.

sp.speaker: Faw.
sp.p: It's well Sir, the cur'd Cow has ſhort Horns.

sp.speaker: Grin.
sp.p: Now I'm come, from a Bull to a Cow or a Cuckold. Thou wilt make an Aſs of me, I believe by and by.

sp.speaker: Faw
sp.p: Oh no Sir, no man is an Aſs, but of his own making. You may do that for your ſelf, that no body can do For you▪ Your Neighbours may help you to Horns poſſibly, but they can never help you to Ears.

sp.speaker: Grin.
sp.p: To Ears Sirra? why, I never was upon the Pillory, I have •• ars of a natural length.

sp.speaker: Faw.
sp.p: You mean I believe Sir, of the length of a natural.

sp.speaker: Grin.
sp.p: A natural▪ ha' a natural? what doeſt make a Baſtard of me too?

sp.speaker: Faw.
sp.p: Oh no Sir▪ for though many men have the ill luck to be Baſtards, yet none of them are naturals, but the Byblows of Princes. You are a • honeſt Gentleman, and ſo was your Mother before you.

sp.speaker: Grin.
sp.p: Thou nonſenſical Owl, my Mother before me a Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Faw.
sp.p: And why not I pray Sir, as well as the Gray Mare be the better Horſe, Your Father was plain George Grindon, but your Mother was Mrs Betty Courtney.

sp.speaker: Grin.
sp.p: Well, and what am I then?

sp.speaker: Faw.
sp.p: Sir, you are Mr. Grindon at every word.

sp.speaker: Grin.
sp.p: what, do I grin at every word? Juſt now he would make me to ſnarl at every man; now I grin at every word. This pitiful fellow will make a Dog of me by and by.

sp.speaker: Faw.
sp.p: Oh no Sir, far be it f • om me; you are the meekeſt Spaniel upon Earth.

sp.speaker: Grin.
sp.p: Upon Earth? It's well I am not a Water-Spaniel too.

sp.speaker: Faw.
sp.p: I'm ſorry Sir, that you ſhould ſo miſ • apply all my words.

sp.speaker: Grin
sp.p: Miſ-apply? ha' miſ-apply? He made me a Conju • er juſt now, in ſaying I could interpret; and now he will make a Parſon of me, which is next to it. For none can miſ-apply, out thoſe that apply; and that you know is the Parſon's Trade.

sp.speaker: Faw.
sp.p:
You ſpeak wi • tily Mr. Grindon;
but under Correction, that's not the Parſon's Trade, but yours and mine.

sp.speaker: Grin.
sp.p: I never heard a man ſpeak ſacriledge till now. A Parſon, and yet not apply to himſelf, the things that he teaches us?

sp.speaker: Faw.
sp.p: Sir, he is left to his liberty, as Phyſicians are, who forbid their Patients many things, that are found upon their own Trenchers.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: What have you to do with Phyſicians, friend?

sp.speaker: Faw.
sp.p: Not much Sir, I thank my good Stars. But this Gentleman, my good Neighbour may poſſibly nee • Relief from you.

sp.speaker: Grin.
sp.p: Relief? He'll make a begger of me too, I think.

sp.speaker: Faw.
sp.p: I mean Sir, you may be beholden to him for his Directions.

sp.speaker: Grin.
sp.p: Thou Idiot, I ſcorn to be beholden to any man: My Landlord here has good Money of me for bad Land.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: No, no, Mr. Grindon, you are not beholden to me; I am rather beholden to you.

sp.speaker: Grin.
sp.p:
Nay, if I thought ſo, • would throw up all my Land: For I will never
keep a Farm meerly to gratifie my Landlord.

sp.speaker: Faw.
sp.p: Me thinks, though you be Mr. Grindon, and my very good Neighbour, you are very humorous Sir.

sp.speaker: Grin.
sp.p: Humorous? Now I warrant he will make me ſick too, and put me into the hands of this Doctor.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: I doubt indeed Sir, you do abound with Humors. But I perceive they are not very groſs and feculent, but ſerous and fine Humors.

sp.speaker: Grin.
sp.p: For all your fine words Mr. Doctor, I do not ſo abound with Humors, as to humour you with a Fee to purge 'em.

sp.speaker: Faw.
sp.p: I pray Sir, do not fall into a peeviſh Humour, of all others.

sp.speaker: Grin.
sp.p: Peeviſh? Now he makes a Child of me. I pray good folk, keep the Child from being peeviſh. Muſt I not have a Nurſe, and a Pa • too?

sp.speaker: Faw.
sp.p: Oh Sir, we know you have a good Nurſe at home, and it is a ſign you are not at home now, if you were, ſhe would not ſuffer this Feather to ſtick upon your Coat.—He takes it off.

sp.speaker: Grin.
sp.p: Thou envious Fellow, why wouldſt thou hinder the world from knowing that I lie upon a feather-Bed?

sp.speaker: Fawn.
sp.p: This is not not a Feather • oo I hope—he bruſhes off ſome duſt from his Shoulder with his hand.—This is duſt Sir.

sp.speaker: Grin.
sp.p: Thou ſawcy Fellow: I carry it on purpoſe to be a Monitor of my Mortality; and doſt thou bruſh it off? Give me my duſt again.

sp.speaker: Faw.
sp.p: —Stoops, and takes up a handful, and lays it upon his ſhoulde ••

sp.speaker: Grin.
sp.p: This is not duſtying •• e, Sirrah, this is daubing me. It were a good deed to reduce thee to the duſt and a ſhadow

sp.speaker: Faw.
sp.p: Sir, I am meaner than a ſhadow; for I honour your ſhadow, yea, the ſhadow of your • hoe • ties.

sp.speaker: Grin
sp.p: They are Buckles Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Faw.
sp.p: Still Sir, will be meeker than they, and buckle to your very Buckle.

sp.speaker: Grin.
sp.p: Thou art a diſſembling Knave, Fawns.

sp.speaker: Faw.
sp.p:
Some men are ſo profeſſedly,
without diſſembling, it's well your Worſhip ſcap'd.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Nay, now he Worſhips you, Mr. Grindon, you muſt be reconcil'd: I pray walk in and drink a Glaſs of the beſt, and be friends.

sp.speaker: Grin.
sp.p: A Glaſs, ha a Glaſs? a poor modicum. But come Frank, if it muſt be but a Glaſs, it ſhall be as big as a looking Glaſs.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Call in Stephen Sad.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: He'll make you all Melancholick, I doubt Sir.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Poor man, poſſibly we may make him merry,—Exit Speed. A very honeſt fellow: But he's always laying one thing or other to Heart, preſent or future. If he feels nothing to trouble him, yet he fears ſomething.—Enter Speed with Sad and Merry skipping after them.

lg.l: Oh Derry, derry, my Rent is paid my Rent is paid,
Oh Derry, derry, my Rent is paid, is paid,
And fye upon all Fools
That are ſuch very Tools,
That their Rent is unpaid, unpay'd.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Why how now, Moſes? who ſent for you?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: If't pleaſe your Worſhip, I'm like ill Weather, I come without ſending for.

lg.l: And as the fair Fountain ſprings, and ſprings,
Which by no Mud is ſtay'd
E'ne ſo poor Merry ſings, and ſings,
Becauſe his Rent is pay'd.

sp.p: Come have a good Heart Stephen; thy Rent's pay'd too, lad.

sp.speaker: Sad.
sp.p: Ay Moſes; but Lady-day will come after Michaelmas.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Ay and Michaelmas▪ after that again.

lg.l: —And ſo the year goes round.
But let's be merry whilſt we may.
Till we be under ground.

sp.speaker: Sad.
sp.p: Sure Moſes you draw a light Harrow. You are always full of mirth I know; but what makes you ſo full of Rhymes?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Why ſhould not the Heart ſympathize with the Purſe, and be both light together?

lg.l: Who can ſing ſo merry a Note,
As he that cannot change a Groat?
And as for rhyming, lad, thou know'ſt,
Poet and Pot differ but in a Letter.
The Pot, oh th' Pot, does make me rhyme the better.

sp.speaker: Sad.
sp.p: But how many poor People of the ſame make with our ſelves are now crying for Bread, and lamen • ing in Proſe?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
And who can help it Lad? they muſt e'ne put their Tears into Tune,
and then they will be as merry as Moſes.

sp.speaker: Sad.
sp.p: Oh but can you think of this great Tax that is coming, and be ſo merry?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
Tax, Stephen? I am thinking, further than ſo. I am thinking how merry we ſhall be, when we have conquer'd France, and drink nothing but Cla
••• .

sp.speaker: Sad.
sp.p: Ah Moſes, I wiſh I may never want good ſmall beer till then. In the mean time, whilſt the Graſs grows, the Steed ſtarves. I doubt we ſhall want Whey before we get Clarett.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Why Lad; we'll make the Pigs drink Water, before we'll want Whey. Have a good heart Stephen.

lg.l: Come caſt away Care,
For ſure we are,
The Pariſh is bound to find us;
Thou muſt die,
And ſo muſt I,
And leave this World behind us.

sp.speaker: Sad.
sp.p: Ah Moſes, Moſes, if we come to the Pariſhes finding, I doubt we ſhall go with many a ſhort Meal.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Nay Stephen, ſo they be but many, I care not how ſhort they are: a little, and often is the beſt feeding.

sp.speaker: Sad.
sp.p: But what if the Turks or French come in upon us, and cut our Throats?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Why then our Breath will go out of the Gap: And is no • that as good as if it went out at our Noſtrils?

sp.speaker: Sad.
sp.p: What if the Sea ſhould overflow this Iſland?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Then we ſhould have plenty of Fiſh; and that's very good Victuals.

sp.speaker: Sad.
sp.p: But what if the Sky ſhould fall?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Then we ſhould catch plenty of Larks, which are now worth ſix pence a dozen.

sp.speaker: Sad.
sp.p: I pray thee now, Moſes, be not ſo mad-headed. Who can be merry, that lives in an Age of Fools and Knaves and Beggars and Mad men▪ as we do?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: And I pray thee Stephen, who can help it? There will be Fools and Knaves as long as you and I • ive; and Beggars too, as long as my Landlord lives.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Why Merry, do I make any Beggars?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: I beg your Worſhips pardon; I mean, whilſt there are any rich, • ere will be ſome poor to beſtow their Eſtutes upon: elſe what ſhould they be rich for?

sp.speaker: Caſ.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I do adviſe you to beware of Extremes. Stephen, it is good to be thoughtful, but not frightful; to be cautious, but not jealous; to be •• uſing, but not miſdeeming. Take heed your grave Seriouſneſs do not • urn into Sadneſs; or however, be ſure it be ſober ſadneſs. And you Moſes▪ in all your Merriment, remember to be merry and wiſe.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: I thank your grave Advi • e, Reverend Father. I will be ſure to remember the firſt; and as for the latter, I leave it amongſt you Book-learn'd Men, make the beſt you can of it. But they ſay, one cannot be wiſe and merry too. If it can be, then I cray you Wiſe Men, reſt ye merry.

sp.speaker: Kill.
sp.p: Your Worſhips moſt humble ſervant, Sir Francis.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: What Keſter? Art thou come again? I'm glad to ſee thee, thou art welcome into England again. Thou haſt ſcap't many a ſcowring, I warrant thee amongſt the Teagues.

sp.speaker: Kill.
sp.p: Scap't many a ſcowring? Ay Sir, and ſo muſt every body that comes there. I believe they are the greateſt fluts in Nature? They made no waſhing, till I came to waſh 'em in •• eir own Blood.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: In their own Urine rather.

sp.speaker: Kill.
sp.p: Why has any body told your Worſhip what havock I have made there? Beſides the many hundreds tha • I have killed, I have made thouſands bepiſs 'em.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: I warrant thou canſt ſhew me many a fair wound, Keſter.

sp.speaker: Kill.
sp.p:
Ay▪ Sir Francis, and theſe in fair places too. But it is no matter for troubling your Worſhip with ſuch a ſad ſight: Beſides, it may be theſe ſtrangers are ſqueamiſh or cowardly, and cannot or dare not look upon Wounds. But good Sir Francis, how do my Wife and Children amongſt you. I have not been at
home yet. I made my firſt viſit to your Worſhip.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: They are all well at home Keſter, as you left 'em.

sp.speaker: Kill.

lg.l: Bleſt Heavens do favour Williams Friends,
And all that to their welfare tends.
Lilly bo • aro, &c.

sp.p: I hope I am come in good time Landlord, to pay my Michaelmas Rent.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: In the very nick of time Keſter; that is, if thou haſt brought any Money with thee.

sp.speaker: Keſt.
sp.p: Money, Landlord? Hold your Hand, my half years Rent is ten pound; here's nine Guinneys, and ſix and ſix pence in Silver. I pray enter it into your book.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Oh brave Keſter! I did not think the whole Teague-land could have turn'd out ſo much Gold. Thou haſt ſtript ſome Captain or Collonel, whom ſome body elſe had kill'd.

sp.speaker: Kill.
sp.p: Some body elſe Sir? with theſe Hands.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: What with theſe Hands I pray you?

sp.speaker: Kill.
sp.p: I kill'd that Rogue St. Ruth.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: St. Ruth? why he was kill'd with a Cannon Bullet.

sp.speaker: Kill.
sp.p: Ay, ay Sir Francis, he had a thump o'th' breaſt with a ſixteen pounder, and was mask'rd, but this Sword ended his wretched days. And Sarsfields too.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Sarsfields? Why Sarsfield is gone into France.

sp.speaker: Kill.
sp.p: Well, but I had certainly kill'd him, if he had not gone; ſo that indeed the taking of Limbrick is owing to me.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Why, was you at the Siege of Limbrick?

sp.speaker: Kill.
sp.p: Of Limbrick Sir? I was as at the Siege of Limbrick; and not only of that, but of Carrick-fergus, Tredagh, Dublin, Wick-low, Water-ford, Kill-kenny, Kingſail, Cork, Athlone, Galloway, and what not?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: I perceive Sir, you ſpeak comprehenſively. For ſome of theſe places were ne're beſieg'd at all.

sp.speaker: Kill.
sp.p: It is no matter for that Sir, for if they had been beſieg'd, I'm ſure I ſhould have been ſent for one.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: But I pray Sir, have you been all that Kingdom over?

sp.speaker: Kill.
sp.p:
Over Sir? Ay and over again; from St. Patricks Purgatory in the County
of Tyrone, to the Devils Hole in the County of Kerry.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: I wonder how you ever got out of thoſe diſmal places.

sp.speaker: Kill.
sp.p: Oh Sir, there is no way •• paſſable to an Engliſh Heart, and a German Blade. This Sword with this Hand will cut it's way thorough any Rock, better than any aquafortis.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: But I pray Mr. Killagrew.

sp.speaker: Kill.
sp.p: Sir, my name is Kill-a-crew: and a Crew I have kill'd of the verye •• Vermin that ever the Earth bore.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Well then Mr. Killacrew, how did your Sword make way for you thorough the Bogs?

sp.speaker: Kill.
sp.p: The Bogs Sir? I needed no Sword. I was grown ſo expert, that I made no more of running over the Bogs, than one of you grave ſirs would do of walking along the ſtreets. Did your Gazzette never tell you of my chaſing a party of Rapparees over the Bog of Allain, and killing nine of 'em?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
Now you ſpeak of it, I do remember ſomething of a certain ſtout Souldier that kill'd eight or nine Rapparees upon the bog of Allain, who afterwards, like Cowardly Rogues, ran away to their
Garriſon of Mullingar. But I little thought you had been that Champion.

sp.speaker: Kill.
sp.p: I am the Man Sir, I • eft my▪ Horſe and my Jack-boots at the ſide of a Wood, and theſe Feet carried me to that exploit, and brought me off again.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: I perceive Sir, you have been a zealous ſervant of the Kings: how chance you forſake him now?

sp.speaker: Kill.
sp.p: I forſake him Sir? No; his Enemies forſake him. His Enemies ceaſe, not his Friends.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Come, come, Keſter, tell truly. Are you not come away in ſome diſguſt?

sp.speaker: Kill.
sp.p: Diſguſt, Sir? I tell you, if every Hair on my Head, were a Head, I would adventure it for his ſake, and if every Finger on my Hand were a Hand, I would employ it in his Service. But having conquer'd, I am willing to ſit down in peace, which few Souldiers are. For they that draw the Sword, commonly love to live by it.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p:
Well ſaid, Keſter: For it is no leſs a Vertue to leave off fighting, than it is to fight. Fighting is an honeſt recreation, but a bad Trade: and ſo is talking
as we do. Wherefore if it pleaſe you Gentlemen to walk in, we will entertain honeſt Keſter with the beſt the Houſe will afford, and drink a health to his Maſter.

sp.speaker: Kill.
sp.p: Huzzah! Long live, King William and Queen Mary.

div.head: Epilogus.
div.p:
MY Maſter Sir Francis, gives his ſervice to you all, and commands me to tell you, that if his Houſe were as large as his Heart, you ſhould all lodge all night in the former, as we • l as you are ſure to do in the latter. Though the entertainment was intended for his two great friends the Doctors, and the benefit to redound to his Tenants, yet he thanks you all for the honour you do him in this viſit, and wiſhes himſelf capable (can you blame him?) of entertaining you all like Princes. He is a perſon of a Mind and Temper ample and generous: He gives me leave, that am but his Butler, at any time to entertain as many as the Buttery will hold, with as much Ale as their Bellies will hold. But, alas, he wants room for ſo great a Company; as indeed you may eaſily perceive: For if he had had other room convenient,
he would not have deſecrated his Chappel, as you ſee he has done to cay, for your ſakes. But his Worſhip has commanded me to direct you to certain • nns for accommodation and lodging at his charges. As for preſent accommodation, there is ſcarce a publick Houſe in Town, but can furniſh you. If you intend to lodge, they can alſo furniſh you: only you are to be you lodge at any Man's Houſe that has Horns, you leave no more behind you than you found. As for particular choice. I need give you no directions, they are all good; nay they are all beſt. The Bull has the beſt Mouth, the Bell is the beſt Me •• le, the Stag and the Heart are the beſt Veniſon, The Lamb is the beſt natur'd, the George is the beſt mounted, the Dog has the beſt heels, the Lion has the beſt Heart, the Bear has the beſt back, but the Keys if they be St. Peters, have the beſt authority. The Peacock has the beſt Feathers, the Swan has the beſt Neck, the Royal Pate has the beſt Brains, but the Vine, (oh the Vine!) affords the beſt Liquor. But, if after all, you would know my opinion, the Eagle that carries away the Child is our beſt Emblem, ſhe wil • mount
all the pretty Lads into the Skies upon the Wings of Fame, and ſo every Boy ſhall be a Ganymedes. And I aſſure you to be a Butler to Jupiter is no ſmall preferment.
And now Gentlemen, as we met lovers, I hope we ſhall part friends.

div.head: ERRATA.
div.p: PAge 3. l. 9. r. ſwet, l. 24. r. there, P. 5. l. 9. r. nomine, p. 6. l. 15. r. giving, P. 10. l. 1. r. ſmall, p. 15. l. penult. r. humourous, P. 25. l. 10. r. fixing, l. 12. for one r. we, p. 32. l. penult, for he is r. you be, p. 34. l. 3. after talk add much, p. 35. blot out line the 24. p. 39. l. 2. r. Hogs, p. 42. l. 6. after heated add his head, l. 16. r. Cruſt, p. 43. l. penult, r. ſpeak, p. 44. l. 12. and 23. p. 45. l. 12. r. Will, p. 47. l. 5. r. an, p. 61. l. 7. after fodder add too, p. 65. l. 15. r. Scotomia, p. 68. l. 4. r. Papiſt, p. 14. l. 3. r. curs'd, p. 78. l. 17. dele the.
